details.title: A generalized framework for probabilistic design with application to rotors

authors.affiliation: Syst. Eng. & Oper.s Res. Dept., George Mason Univ., Fairfax, VA, USA

p: John F. Shortle is currently an assistant professor of systems engineering at George Mason University. His research interests include simulation, queuing, and reliability, with applications in air transportation and telecommunications. Previously, he worked at U S WEST Advanced Technologies. For work there, he won the Daniel H. Wagner Prize for excellence in Operations Research Practice. He received a B.S. in mathematics from Harvey Mudd College in 1992, and a Ph.D. & M.S. in operations research at UC Berkeley in 1996.

authors.name: J.F. Shortle

p: Max B. Mendel is the founder of Boston Fund Services. Prior to that, he was on the faculty of the Dept. of Industrial Engineering and Operations Research at the University of California, Berkeley. He received his B.S. & M.S. in mechanical engineering from the Delft University of Technology, and a Ph.D. in mechanical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

details.abstract: This paper generalizes an existing method for deriving probability models of manufacturing quality metrics. We specifically consider the problem of deriving probability models for the inertia tensor of a rotor. The inertia tensor is a 3 /spl times/ 3 matrix that determines various dynamical properties of the rotor as it spins, affecting its reliability. The key contribution of this paper is that the quality metric of interest is a matrix or a second-order tensor, and the various manufacturing imperfections that cause deviations in the inertia tensor may be vectors. Existing methods, by contrast, assume that the quality metric, as well as the manufacturing imperfections, are scalar quantities. By using rotational properties of matrices & vectors, we show that the relationship between the inertia tensor, and the manufacturing errors must have a specific form, when the errors are small. This structure significantly restricts the class of allowable distributions for the inertia tensor. For example, we show that the multivariate s-normal distribution is not a physically appropriate distribution for the inertia tensor. The results in this paper, while applied specifically to the inertia tensor, are general, and depend only on transformational properties of vectors & matrices. Thus, the framework is applicable to modeling other engineering systems involving second-order tensors, such as the stress tensor, or strain tensor.

links.abstract: This paper presents an application of advanced first-order second-moment (AFOSM) reliability method to probabilistic design of integrated circuits with correlated parameters. The method avoids the transformation to the space of uncorrelated parameters and provides a conservative estimate of the yield. Optimal nominal values are found such that the cost of tolerances is minimized while the desired yield is achieved. Numerical results are presented for a switched capacitor filter and verified by M...

references.text: A. Seifi, K. Ponnambalam, J. Vlach, "Probabilistic design of integrated circuits with correlated input parameters", IEEE Trans. Computer-Aided Design of Integrated Circuits and Systems, vol. 18, no. 8, pp. 1214-1219, 1999.

context.text: In fact, many common multivariate distributions that have been used to model random matrices; namely the multivariate \$s\$-normal, the multivariate Cauchy, and the Wishart distributions [8]; are not physically appropriate distributions for the inertia tensor of a rotor.
Similarly, multi-variate Cauchy, and Wishart distributions [8] are inappropriate models for the inertia tensor.

references.title: Integrated micro-electro-mechanical sensor development for inertial applications

context.text: These imperfections occur in the production of a micro-machined gyroscope [11], [12], and can be modeled as vectors.

Example: A micro-machined gyroscope (e.g., [11], [12]) is made through a process called ion-etching [16]. (The gyroscope has an outer radius of about 250 \$\mu{\rm m}\$, and a height of about 2 \$\mu{\rm m}\$.) This process leaves a sidewall taper \$\Delta r\$ that is roughly uniform around the gyroscope (see Fig. 2).

links.abstract: Electronic sensing circuitry and micro-electro-mechanical sense elements can be integrated to produce inertial instruments for applications unheard of a few years ago. This paper describes the Sandia M/sup 3/EMS fabrication process, inertial instruments that have been fabricated, and the results of initial characterization tests of micro-machined accelerometers.

references.text: J. J. Allen, "Integrated micro-electro-mechanical sensor development for inertial applications", IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine, vol. 13, no. 11, pp. 36-40, 1998.

links.abstract: A model is developed for the response of a micromachined, rotary gyroscope subject to a general input motion. The governing equations are formulated for weakly nonlinear oscillations of the rotor, suspended above the moving substrate via elastic beams. The method of multiple scales is used to separate the slow and fast responses. This approach allows quick computation of the long-term behavior of the rotor without the need to integrate over fast oscillations. The power of the model to evince cro...

references.text: E. Kanso, A. J. Szeri, A. P. Pisano, "Cross-coupling errors of micromachined gyroscopes", J. of Microelectromechanical Systems, vol. 13, no. 2, pp. 323-331, 2004.

links.abstract: Airbag deployment systems demand reliable, inexpensive sensing of deceleration of the car during collision. The integrated accelerometer combines a 0.3 mm/sup 2/ micromechanical capacitive sensing element with precision bipolar/MOS control circuitry in a 9 mm/sup 2/ area. The microstructure is fabricated from a layer of deposited polysilicon by surface micromachining. This chip is an A/V (acceleration-to-voltage) functional block for accelerations of 1 to 50 g. This paper reviews the rationale f...

references.text: R. S. Payne, S. Sherman, S. Lewis, R. T. Howe, "Surface micromachining: from vision to reality to vision", IEEE International Solid State Circuits Conference, pp. 164-165, 1995.
